title: Haloacetic acids - lowest boiling point and why

content.description:
The structure of haloacetic acids, <math alttext="X C H 2 C O O H " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>XC</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>COOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (where <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is either <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="C l" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B r" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, or <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), is shown above. The dissociation constants and molar masses of four haloacetic acids are listed in the table below.

Acid

 <math alttext="K sub a" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Molar Mass<math alttext="in grams per mole" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

Fluoroacetic acid
 <math alttext="2.59" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.59</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2.57 times 10 to the negative 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.57</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="78.0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>78.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Chloroacetic acid
 <math alttext="2.87" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.87</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.35 times 10 to the negative 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.35</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="94.5" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>94.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Bromoacetic acid
 <math alttext="2.90" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.26 times 10 the negative 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.26</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="138.9" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>138.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Iodoacetic acid
 <math alttext="3.18" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.61 times 10 to the negative 4" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.61</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="185.9" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>185.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Which compound, chloroacetic acid or iodoacetic acid, most likely has the lower boiling point, and why?

choices.label: Chloroacetic acid, because the London dispersion forces among its molecules are weaker.
Chloroacetic acid, because the dipole-dipole forces among its molecules are weaker.
Iodoacetic acid, because the London dispersion forces among its molecules are stronger.
Iodoacetic acid, because the dipole-dipole forces among its molecules are stronger.

content.answer: Chloroacetic acid, because the London dispersion forces among its molecules are weaker.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
